author: alon.ssv.network
content:
> <@!636950487089938462> how do you define a decentralised trustless pool?
> if a user controls their own validator keys and their withdrawal keys to a contract, isn't that as trustless as it gets? 
> (maybe not completely as the contract could theoretically be 'upgraded' to one that steals the ETH it receives)
<@!687950695218937857> I guess an open network without a centralised (or semi centralised) point of failure will be a good definition. 
Basically, anyone can join the network as an operator or a user and no single entity in that network has a privileged authority/ position over any other entity.
An add-on on that will be a network protocol which has the right incentives and design to promote decentralisation of power.

author: pieterastra
content: so any contract upgrades would have to be done by a DAO, or something like that

author: alon.ssv.network
content:
> is there a good place to go and see the ELI5 explanation of the trustless pool construction?
<@!336569819833040898> design goals in mind will be: stake any amount, no need to run infra (for the end user) and liquidity via tokenization of the stake

A pool network will consists of 3 parts
1) Pool level: a protocol to operate an eth2 validator keys in a distributed way  
2) Consensus layer that bids all the pools together (rewards, penalties, creation/ liquidation of pools, etc.)
3) Tokonomics to incentivise node operators to actually join the network instead of just staking solo

author: alon.ssv.network
content:
> so any contract upgrades would have to be done by a DAO, or something like that
<@!687950695218937857> It's more nuanced than that. There are a few moving pieces in the life cycle of a pool, from creation to operation, to rewards/ penalties, to liquidation and anything in between. 
If one part is highly centralised it can compromise the entire network. For example, if you tokenise the stake and have a contract which manages that but that contract is controlled by a centralised entity than a big part of that network is centralised.
Another example will be enforcing network actions on individual pools like liquidation.
